supportDesc.foliation: Foliation in pencil in the upper outer corner.

item.desc: Note recording the purchase of the book by , his donation of the book to Tābota Ṣəyon, and an exhortation for the priests and deacons who read it to pray for him and his wife. It is unclear if the Tābota Ṣəyon that is mentioned is a church or perhaps only a tābot.
item.q: ዛቲ፡ መጽሐፍ፡ ዘተሣየጠ፡ በንዋዩ፡ ገብረ፡ ኢየሱስ፡ ወወሀባ፡ ለተቦተጽዮን፡ ከመ፡ ታንብሮ፡ ደርገ፡ ምስለ፡ ምእመናን፡ አመ፡ ዕለተ፡ ፍዳ፡ ወደይን፡ ወምስለ፡ ቡሩካን፡ ጻድቃን፡ ለዓለመ፡ ዓለም፡ አሜን፡ እንዘ፡ ያነ፡ ብቡ፡ ቀሳውስት፡ ወዲያቆናት፡ ለእመ፡ ኢተ፡ ዘክሩ፡ ስሞ፡ ወስመ፡ ብእሲቱ፡ ወለተ፡ ኪዳን፡ ውጉዛነ፡ ይኩኑ፡ በስልጣነ፡ ጴጥሮስ፡ ወጳውሎስ፡ ወበ፡ አፈ፡ ቄርሎስ፡

item.desc:
Note recording the purchase of the book by
containing an exhortation for the priests and deacons who read it to pray for him and his wife.
item.q: ዛቲ፡ መጽሐፍ፡ ዘተሣየጠ፡ በንዋዩ፡ ገብረ፡ ኢየሱስ፡ ኦዘያነብቡ፡ ካህናት፡ ወዲያቆናት፡ ለእመ፡ ኢጸውኡ፡ ስሞ፡ ወስመ፡ ብእሲቱ፡ ወለተ፡ ኪዳን፡ ውጉዛነ፡ ይኩኑ፡ በሥልጣነ፡ ጴጥሮስ፡ ወጳውሎስ፡

item.desc: Paper sticker on the inside of the front board.
Note in Swedish recording the donation of the manuscript by August Bergman to its current repository in 1894.
item.q:
Etiopisk handskrift n. 4
skänkt d. 3 Sept. 1894 till Upsala
Universitetsbibliotek af August Bergman
svenskt missionär i Belleza, Asmara,
i Abyssinien

history.provenance: originally belonged to (cf. ), whereas —possibly produced to complement —originally belonged to . Secondary owner of at least was .
history.acquisition: According to , the manuscript reached its current repository in . It was a gift from August Bergman, who had been active as a missionary in .

handNote.desc: According to 95, the hand is "young and angular" (jung, eckig); 151 describes it as a "crude hand" (rozza mano).

origin.origDate: 1850–1900. , introduced as ʾabuya (an attempt to transfer the title ʾabuna to a first person singular context?) and his son are mentioned in supplications. It is possible that this manuscript part was produced to complement .

msItem.note: identifies this miracle as , and also as .
170 observes that this miracles also appears as Miracle 69.
170 observes that this miracles also appears as Miracle 70.
170 observes that this miracles also appears as Miracle 68.

168 observes that this miracles appears three times in the manuscript: as Miracle 12, as Miracle 39, and as Miracle 61. Miracle 12 and Miracle 61 represent the same recension, whereas Miracle 39 represents another.
170 observes that this miracles also appears—in another recension—as Miracle 67.

168 observes that this miracles appears three times in the manuscript: as Miracle 12, as Miracle 39, and as Miracle 61. Miracle 12 and Miracle 61 represent the same recension, whereas Miracle 39 represents another.
170 observes that this miracles also appears—in another recension—as Miracle 43.
170 observes that this miracles also appears as Miracle 23.
170 observes that this miracles also appears as Miracle 15.
170 observes that this miracles also appears as Miracle 16.

handNote.desc: According to 95, the hand is "good" (gut) and dates from circa 1800. 151 describes it as a "better hand" (una migliore mano) and dates the hand to the 19th century.

527–528 describes the hand in detail and dates it to the first half of the 17th century. According to 95, the hand is "strong and regular" (kräftig, regelmäßig) and dates from c. 1600. 151 describes it as a "beautiful writing" (bella scrittura) and dates the hand to the beginning of the 17th century or the end of the 16th century.
According to 95, the hand is similar to but smaller (ähnlich aber kleiner) and dates from the 18th century. 170 just notes that the hand is different from .

history.origin: 1600–1650 The original owner was . A later owner, as emerged both from and numerous additions in supplications, was . It is unclear if formed part of the manuscript when owned it.
